title: Boring...
review: People whom give this movie a high rating either don't understand it, low IQ, or pretending to be smart.Aliens with advance technologies, capable of light speed or perhaps wormhole travel have the appearance of squids with giant claws. How are they supposed to have the dexterity like we humans does to create, invent things.This is the stucked image we have for aliens since the movie "Alien". Thought this movie brings some intelligence but nope, let down.Arrival, is a slow burn movie with nothing interesting going.Skip this one or watch and be bored.

title: Nothing special, a bit lame
review: The idéa is good but way too boring for a whole movie.

title: I am broken
review: I am not the same person I was before watching this. I won't forget this movie any time soon, I am changed

title: An amazing experience
review: This movie is really beautiful. It was emotional experience that went beyond just watching a movie. The emotions that it evoked in me has stayed with me.

title: Unusual work on an unusual subject
review: A stunningly well made film, well written, and perfectly acted. Few stories have as much potential, and are as often poorly presented, as the now classic First Contact story. As a writer how does one portray something truly "Alien" without becoming overly simplistic, or intentionally horrific? The writer must imagine the impossible to imagine, what it means to be a non-human, even a non-mammal, the writer must understand a being that emerged from a completely different evolutionary pattern, and then have them interact with us. Most stories use an easy route, the Alien is humanoid, allowing the writer to create the story and move on, such as still wonderful and well made "The Day The Earth Stood Still" for example. However in "Arrival" the writer adopted a little known aspect of our own human unconscious actions ( the tendency of how language determines the thought process ) and explores what it would mean if a completely alien species approaches us with no common forms of communication, and we are forced to understand theirs, just as they are forced to understand us.

title: Tries hard to be intelligent
review: Another sci-fi movie that tries to be intelligent but ends up being merely dull. I get it, it's a good question to ask how we will communicate with aliens - but there's so much more that could've made this movie better - it ends up being a boring watch.

title: All "Arrival" movies need to Depart!
review: This movie is just not worth the time and effort that went into making it. It ran out of steam about 10 minutes into the movie and became a rambling and meandering road to nowhere. It's message, if there was one, got lost along the way. It was just......really stupid!

title: Slow start but ultimately worthwhile
review: I expected a typical fast slam bang laser blasting action flick. What I got was what science fiction can be in the hands of good writers. Too many film makers rely on action to disguise the fact they really don't have anything to say. This film isn't like that. It takes you on a journey of discovery into humanity's core. I suspect the bad revues came from young viewers who have the attention span of a housefly or people with all the depth of a birdbath. All in all a thought provoking and hopeful story. We need more of these positive films.

title: Interesting Study Of Language
review: A thought provoking film. Nice visuals and an interesting study of language.

title: It has to be the most implausible and unintelligent movie I ever watched.
review:
The initial idea and the presentation might be good but the execution is just horrible.
It just pulls you out of the story with "This is so stupid, this would never happen".A entire advanced alien race that lands on earth is uncapable to learn our language even while they had the time to prepare in advance, but one random linguist learns it on the go like a regular person that takes a language class or reads a language book to learn a foreign language.Aliens teach the main protagonist literally magic that breaks causality.
Then just disappear, considering their abilities they could have achieved that in couple of minutes without even the rest of the world noticing it.I have to assume this is the dumbest movie ever made, just from a rational perspective.
What is even more shocking is that they even had scientific advisers, best case scenario is that they either didn't listen to them or didn't understand what they said and proceeded without waiting for a feedback.P.S:
U.S. saves the day cliché.
China, Russia and so on start to act evil.

title: One of the best
review: One of the best sci-fi/ Alien movies I have seen. It's a slow burn But it is very much worth it in the end. Give it a watch, you will not regret it.

title: Slow-paced but worth the effort.
review: Many movies are classified as science fiction but really don't deserve the moniker. The Star Wars movies are action fantasy, and the Guardians of the Galaxy movies are pretty much just action. Actual science fiction films, while not exactly rare, are much less common than marketers would have us believe.If you're a fan of Star Wars as science fiction, Arrival isn't for you. It isn't an action movie. It moves slowly and the special effects, while - um - effective, do not dazzle the eye. Arrival is more of a treat for the mind, and the heart, than for the eye. This is a moving and hopeful story, and it goes places where only science fiction can go. Watch it alone, when you're in no hurry, or watch it with someone you love, assuming he or she can appreciate the laconic pacing.There is great beauty here, in a movie that dazzles the soul while not trying to dazzle the eye. Great beauty, for those willing to take it in.Highly recommended.

title: Wow. Just wow.
review: I've just watched Arrival for the first time after seeing it was on the television the other night. Truth be told, I'd never even heard of the film until a few days ago but oh my am I glad I watched it.It's just beautiful. There's not much more I can say. Just a truly beautiful film. Please watch it.

review: I call few movies a 10/10. This is one of those extremely rare, near perfect cinematic works of art. Thought provoking. Emotional. Surprisingly wonderful. I find no flaws. If you haven't seen it, you must.

title: Don't bother
review: As beautiful and "cinematic" as this is, it's boring. The aliens come, the humans struggle to make contact, there's nearly a war but then there isn't and the aliens leave. I have this 2 stars simply because Jeremy Renner is in it

title: I can't believe all the bad reviews!
review: This was a great movie - the acting, cinematography and musical score was amazing. At certain parts of the story I was worried about the ending, but I liked it. I think the romance between the two characters could have been hinted at a bit earlier to show chemistry, But perhaps the twist ending demanded showing so little chemistry. The other thing I would've liked to of seen which would've made this a 10 would be to learn a little bit more about what humans are supposed to do for the aliens 3000 years from now. With that said there was a bit of a plot hole at the end but it didn't deter from the beauty of the ending.

review: I liked the concept, storyline, production, execution but why oh why are the Chinese and Russians yet again the geo political bad guys? Why not just make a great sci-fi without politics?

title: A linguist must decode an entirely foreign language when aliens land on earth.
review: Acting was decent. Plot is oriented towards intrigue and curiosity rather than suspense; not very fast-paced, but it kept my interest (maybe only because I'm interested in linguistics?). title: Arrival (2016, Denis Villeneuve) Brainy science fiction with a hell of a twist
review:
Arrival (2016, Denis Villeneuve)
From auteur Villeneuve creator of such standouts as 'Sicario' and 'Prisoners' comes this extremely cerebral science fiction first contact picture. Much more 'Close Encounters of the Third Kind' than 'Independence Day' this is an exercise in communication as well as a reflection on the nature of our human existence in general. Around the globe in twelve seemingly random locations alien ships appear. Each society handles the arrival in different ways and it seems the reactions run from joy to hysteria. In America the area is quickly sealed off by the military and around the country chaos descends as rioting and looting becomes widespread. In the midst of all that we are introduced to Louise Banks, a linguist, played by Amy Adams and Ian Donnelly, a scientist, played by Jeremy Renner. They are tasked by the military, as the foremost experts in their respective fields, to figure out why the aliens are here on Earth and mainly if their intentions are hostile. The military is represented mainly in the form of Forest Whitaker's Colonel Weber. While he seems to understand the scientist's wont for diplomacy he also has superiors to answer to who are keeping the military on a short leash to a first strike option if no diplomacy can be found. There is a brief window once a day where the humans are allowed to enter the alien ship and interact, of a sort, with two of interstellar travelers. This begins an exhausting yet fascinating back and forth on trying to figure out how to communicate with the aliens. The clock is ticking as other foreign powers, mainly China, appear to be adopting a more aggressive stance toward the aliens. Throughout this we get snippets of Louise's life and she also starts to have visions and as the puzzle pieces are methodically assembled we eventually get to a marvelous twist moment of a sorts that does more than bring the story full circle. It expands our though process on what full circle might mean. This film succeeds on many levels however I still struggle with some of the themes as to how the overall mission of the aliens will wind up affecting mankind going forward. Also as the story is laid out everything works out to the point that if feels a bit contrived. As with many stories that contain a pivotal twist it is hard to discuss certain aspects of these themes without giving away too much. The movie succeeds quite well in what it set out to do and it is fascinating as a brainy science fiction piece as well as a stirring human melodrama and it's only the overarching theme for humanity that I take an issue with but if you buy what is being sold there then the film vaults from very good to possibly one of the best of the year.
Eric's Grade: B

title: Brilliant!
review: An amazing audio-visual treat with some brilliant performance from the main cast, and a profound narrative! A classic in the making.

title: I don't get it
review: This film is a real struggle for me, a struggle to get the hype. Too much pomp over circumstance and its tragic, because up to 50% through the menace of this film kept me on the edge of my seat, only to disapoint in the most sensational way I hgave ever experienced.

title: Absolutely different sci-fi movie but still very good in its own way
review: I saw ARRIVAL out of curiosity because I like sci-fi movies from time to time and also because of its cast. This is one of those movies that divides audiences, in the sense that critics love it but the general public mostly doesn't understand it, as it's a sci-fi movie unlike STAR WARS or ALIEN.In this movie, some enormous space ships suddenly appear all over the world and people asks what they are doing there. Soon, Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) goes to Dr. Banks' (Amy Adams) office and asks her to join a team of researchers in the American west as she has impressive linguistic skills and will be helpful to try to communicate with the creatures inside the space ships (and they are HUGE). What follows is an incredibly cerebral movie a bit slow at times but still capable to capture the viewer's attention from time to time.The acting is probably the best asset in the movie. Amy Adams gives a very deep performance, and actually one of her best. Jeremy Renner is also very good effortlessly and Forest Whitaker is the standout of the supporting players The soundtrack is also very haunting and enhances a lot of the movie's actions. Denis Villeneuve's direction is great, not in the same level of PRISONERS but still great.In substance, a disivive movie that I liked but more in an appreciation sort of way and that at times left me a bit confused.

title: Made me think different about the importance of language and communication
review: Watched it a second time after a few days, to check if it's really a masterpiece. Turns out, it is still one of the best movies I've ever seen!

title: The movie never concludes.
review: Too many important yet simple questions about the characters life left unanswered.

title: Unbelievable ... but in a bad way
review: Unfortunately there are too few "serious" alien themed movies that don't involve massive explosions, CGI and fantastical scenes of armageddon. With more previously-classified information being released to the public in recent years, the topic of UFOs and "extraterrestrials" is becoming more mainstream and less the realm of those who like to sport tinfoil hats on the weekends. As such, Arrival would have been a wonderful opportunity to imagine and examine what it would be like if we made contact and tried to communicate with aliens who landed on our planet. But, instead, it totally misses the mark.My biggest gripe is that the film lacks intelligence and complexity. It reduces humans to being brainless warmongers while aliens, who've presumably developed advanced technology to travel light years, to altruistic yet helpless, self-sacrificing pacifists. Nothing about this movie is believable! Even the discussion of linguistics totally lacks creativity or study for that matter. Let's not even bring up the topic of physics or lack thereof. Also, why is the US Army handling an event that would undoubtedly be in purview of the Air Force and why would a Colonel be calling all the shots for something of this magnitude?Overall, the acting is subpar as well (I don't know anyone who'd believe Whittaker's horrible attempt at a Bostonian accent and why would anyone write it in the script for him?). Adams and Renner are very talented actors but neither fit the part, by a long shot. I'm afraid their chemistry is also very weak.Finally, the need for an incredibly sad subplot involving of the illness and loss of the protagonist's daughter is also lost on me. The tragic imagery is clearly intended to evoke emotion but it just seems incredibly forced and out of place. Such serious cinematic themes deserve more depth.In all, I think I'm being generous by giving this movie 4.5 stars.

title: Good but not great
review: Plenty of other reviews sum up the plot. What is good about this movie: the aliens are not some version of humanoid, talking acting thinking processing like humans. Even their language is different in numerous ways. That was refreshing. Amy Adams gave a solid performance. The idea of how complicated it is to learn a new language, especially if you are starting from scratch. What is not good about the movie: the bad guys were once again the Chinese and Russians. Again the military symbolized stupid, war hungry, rule following idiots with zero depth. Jeremy Renner's character was boring to the point of distraction. The coloring of the movie was way too bleak. Grey and blue in about 90% of the scenes. The discovery of the very basics of their language and how humans actually figure out what the various circle words meant was never explained and would have been very interesting to see. I was invested in AA's character, but beyond her I only cared about the two aliens. None of the other characters had any connection to the audience at all.

title: It's a masterpiece. Period.
review: I will help you choose if you want to watch this one or not. It's easy. If you like, for example Sixth Sense, you will love this one. If you prefer Independence Day, you will hate it.I think it's a masterpiece. Period. I'm actually a bit shocked it's not closer to 9 and a top 20 all time movie. The script is so intelligent that it feels that you have watched 4 different movies in the end. It's a thrill ride for drama-, thriller-, action- and science fiction fans in one package.I had to compose myself for 20 minutes before leaving the theatre and it took me and my wife about 3 hours and 3 glasses of wine to talk about it afterwards.

title: Bittersweet fairytale
review:
A bittersweet fairytale about the hope that will never be fulfilled: humanity united.
We can still dream of it...

title: Amazing
review: I really liked it it's a interesting and a different film to watch

title: This will make you think
review: If you are looking for a typical alien/ sci fi movie this is not it. This film is not action packed in fact not a lot happens but the journey of what we as the audience and also the protagonist learns, as the storyline develops, is so powerful. It's been a while since I watched this film but I find myself thinking about it far more often than I have ever thought about any other film. I had knowledge of the linguistic research the story is inspired by before watching and I don't know if that makes a difference to how this film is received. However I really would recommend this.

title: Decent.
review: Nothing very special about the movie, can say the script was pretty much traditional sci-fi. Although a few things were not clear and unnecessary, the movie overall is decent to watch. Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner have done a good job to bring life to the ordinary script hence the good rating!!

title: A Memorable Film
review:
The first hour of the film felt so real to me, even though I watched it a while ago using tablet! It just struck me as I related with Dr. Banks (the linguist in the film & the main character), and I felt her fear as she entered the column to see the aliens for the first time. I nearly thought it was my first time to see aliens when I looked at the glass windows where aliens were about to arrive. So it was such a memorable film to me. Like a semi-documentary semi-Sci-Fi film, and since I don't want to spoil things, I want to mention that the story would leave you pondering upon philosophical things that you might not have thought of. At least the film made me think of the meanings of time in my life, how my existence meant in the entire universe, and how languages changed my perception of time. AND SO ON.
Love this film forever.

title: Circle
review: Everything is connected. Try to understand and live your life.

title: Lame and pretentious
review: For a movie to qualify as a sci-fi there must be at least some sliver of the science in it. This pretentious muddle is using teenage philosophy musing as a scientific step up, and it does not work. So the premise is hollow, the acting non existent, half of the actors are in for no real reason, and they are all trundling in semi-darkness. Then, there is an inevitable political statement that is one step beyond laughable. Are people really impressed with this sort of tripe?

title: Great Sci-Fi and outstanding production!
review: I love and appreciate this movie much more than one can for a cult-classic."Arrival" is a hard Science Fiction film that takes a unique look on mankind's first interactions with humans and discusses communication, culture, and - most importantly - compassion.Brilliant writing and outstanding performances from both Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner.Fair warning that while the story is beautiful, and I personally believe an optimistic narrative, it does deal with some heavy overtones.If you're looking for a fun party movie, this is not your flick. If you are a connoisseur of direction, a wannabe writer, a young actor, a cinephile, or just a plain-out fan of altogether awesome production, look no further!

title: Painful to watch. A long slog. Nonsensical.
review: First off: i had to crank the volume up to 11 to hear any of the speech....and then got blasted by the sound fx and music. Why were they all whispering?The aliens: octopuses. How how how could a fifty feet tall octopus design and build a complicated craft capable of traversing the universe? Ok, they might not have fingers but they would need to manipulate tiny components. Not with octopus testicles that's for sure.The linguist is totally unbelievable. Nothing of her genius is explained. And what is all that weepy flashback nonsense...? And the last second forgotten phone call to China?And the bomb in the saucer...? What...!Give it a miss. Or sleep...

title: The movie was bland and uninteresting
review: I'm not here to judge what others saw in this movie, but it clearly seems like they watched a different movie. This movie was hardly interesting after initial exploration. It seems like people clearly were awe-inspired by a sudden revelation which wasn't even that ground-breaking. The movie was all bland but Jeremy and Amy did their part well. The story-line was stretched and cinematography wasn't engaging enough. Avoidable!

title: Yawn
review: I don't like movies about aliens to begin with, I don't believe they exist and anyone who believes otherwise is a nutcase, period.There are good alien movies though, but this one was extremely boring, incoherent and unrealistic even if we assume that aliens exist and try to communicate.There was a half-hearted attempt to include a subplot about the protagonist's future daughter, but it was weak.There is also some unnecessary propaganda thrown in about how great China and its leader is is to appease the Chinese audience, which was annoyingly obvious.If you want to waste your time or need something to help you fall asleep, this is the movie for you.

title: Existential & Beautiful
review: I came to Arrival expecting to see an entertaining blockbuster alien sci-fi thrillers, sort of like Skyline. But instead, my god, I got something light years better! It made me think and feel at the same time afterwards. No films have made me this way. A perfect amalgamation of intellectual prose and emotional poetry. It was existential and beautiful... at the same time. Very few films can coalesce these two hallmarks so harmoniously and poetically - exploring the existential concept of time & language and then makes us see how it'd influence you on a profound emotional level. If you can have your whole life lays out before your eyes from start to finish, would you change things? Arrival has become one of my favorite films of all time!

title: Worst Film I Have Ever Watched
review: Ok. I am not the biggest movie junkie that exists, but I do love a good film, and critique films with knowledge that I do have, (sometimes limited). I literally made an account on IMDB to review this film and say that it is the WORST, and I've seen some pretty bad films, WORST film I have ever, I repeat, EVER seen.These aliens are like giants balls with legs, so cheap man, and don't even get me started on the plot of the movie. What is even happening in this film. I kept waiting, and waiting, and waiting, because I was so excited to see it!!! title: Couldn't like it more
review: Absolutely amazing piece of art. Great storytelling, depth, good picture, music and actors.

title: Sci-fi masterpiece
review: I am a sci-fi enthusiast and this is one of the best sci-fi movies in recent times. It is beautifully paced and is a fantastic exposition of language and human nature. It is a must watch.

title: One of my least favourite
review:
I know everyone even around me loves this movie but to me it is one of the worst. I like the acting and the melancholy vibe, but I dont get why did they have to do it so emotional and tragic? I found the plot twist quite uninteresting and the whole movie quite boring and slow.
I had very high hopes for it because of the actors and the acting itself but to me this was one of the most blah movies out there.

title: Its giving you some real life questions
review: I dont think that I overaexaggerate when I say that this film is giving you some real thinking about life, time and our place here on earth.It demonstrates that time is merely a relative thing and so is feelings such as pain and suffering.The film circulates around a team of scientists who is hired by their government (the main characters are american) when the world all of a sudden is covered by these huge tall circulare shaped floating objects who they realise are UFO's.The team is hired to try and communicate with the beeings who are inhabiting these apparent flying vehicles.During the movie we find out that the aliens are communicating on a completely different level which is none linear and using different bodily scenses as a communication way.The film really makes you think about how small pieace of what life and our place here is that we really know and how communication is of utter importance if we want to understand the world we live in and ourselves.The actors are really good and some amazing scenery.Highly recommend it!

title: Amazing movie
review: I don't expect this movie is so good. Louise is brave and she don't leave Hannah when Hannah will die when she is older. Amazing movie! This is the best I have seen. 😍😍😍

title: what is time
review: A good movie which is unexpected. Time is not going forward but can go back and forth. Really amazed knowing she has not given birth to Hannah but still go ahead even knowing she is going to die. And intelligent aliens ...

title: Intellectual and entertaining science fiction
review: Absolute travesty that this film didn't win best Oscar for film and Amy Adams performance. It's one of those few films where repeated watches continue to reveal fresh nuances even though one may already understand the brilliant story arch. Highly recommended for those willing to invest the time, unfortunately many may dismiss it as too much like hard work.

title: Good, but overrated
review: I am really into time-shifting movies from 12 Monkeys, all Nolan films (Memento et al), Looper, Triangle, Primer.. you name it, I probably have seen it and loved it. The concept of changing one's perception of time through the use of language/communication is great and although I didn't know the direction this movie was going, I suspected it would go this way at a certain point.My problem with this movie is: Like I said above, it is a concept (or an idea if you will), and that does not make it a good story. Just because time-shifting is involved, does not make the story great, it is the context in which that happens! And that context was weak in this movie. The movie is very slow-paced, that is okay in general, but there is no character evolution in this movie, they are all just there, and the storytelling has to keep a lid on the only thing that is important to these otherwise boring characters: The fact that the flashbacks are flash-forwards into the future. That is everything that has to be kept away from the viewer for like most of the movie. Only in the last ca. 15 minutes it is disclosed to the viewer.. and then I realized that the whole "story" was preparing for this disclosure.. and when it was there I was like.. "okay that's it?" The plot is exactly the same as Close Encounters of the Third Kind, just leave out the mountain. (Weaker script in my opinion)Personally I didn't like the casting and performances of the main actors. Forrest Whitaker was okay, not great, but okay. And Amy Adams was way too kitsch-y at times and the other guy I forgot after 5 minutes, he was just there to prove to the audience what a genius Louise is.Conclusion: If you are a time-shift movie buff like me, you should not expect too much. If you are more interested in acting, it will probably be a better movie for you. If you are interested in alien communication you would probably think that the "Close Encounters of the Third Kind"-approach with sounds and melody would be the more realistic way to do it

title: A great artistic sci-fi film that will blow your mind!
review: Plot:A linguist works with the military to communicate with alien lifeforms after twelve mysterious spacecrafts appear around the world.Analysis:Alien invasion was a movie theme that was heavily explored in previous decades, the idea of a whole new civilization that tries to reach us is not a new subject and it was always a very interesting "what if" situation. Most of the films chose the easy way of a huge war with special effects and constant battles, a fight that unites the humanity. Arrival isn't your typical sci-fi, it's a slow poetic drama that tries to examine this idea way beyond the stereotypes and try to find new meaning and messages that can be portrayed in that interaction.Instead of a fast paced movie full of adrenaline, Villeneuve tries to create a memorable drama that unfolds its story slowly, so the viewer can process the information and spot the little details that solve the puzzle of this plot. Step by step this movie becomes a more and more interesting mystery that shows a lot about human nature and language, some things that very few movies managed to do properly. It's a passionate effort to create something completely new, something memorable to open a new chapter in this genre and this success is a win for art against the commercialization of cinema. A movie theme that was used only for brainless action movies was redefined by an idealist who wants to find meaning behind every action and every little detail, that's way more than a well-written movie, that's what art is about and whether you like it or not, this film is art.The realizations about mankind in this movie are mindblowing. The way this situation is handled by those in charge and the impact of this alien arrival transfers perfectly the feeling of colonialism and how the language is decoded, created and used to achieve communication. This one goes beyond the surface and explores the whole foundation of living creatures' interaction the way no one ever did, a poetic amazing experience that will not and should not be forgotten. Our language in the tool to explore life and this movie takes this basic statement to another level, beyond any imagination, leaving the audience stunned.This amazing story was perfected by the talent of two very gifted actors like Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner. Their characters are the two sides to explore a unique situation and examine an alien race, the theoritical side represented by the famous linguist Louise Banks and the practical side represented by the physicist Ian Donnely. The two of them have to figure out the situation and overcome the obstacle of lacking foundation, to communicate and understand the purpose of this unexpected visit. Both of them did a very good job, but Adams was the one who stole the show in this film, her breathtaking performance was not only the result of a well written character but also a great example of her unique talent.Just by looking at this movie you can understand why it has been described by many as a masterpiece. Gorgeous looking image that will take your breath away, incredibly realistic special effects that turned imagination into reality and perfect use of camerawork to capture the every necessary detail. Whether it is an alien symbol on a wall or a character's facial expression, Villeneuve will give the most breathtaking shot to maximize the impact, a free masterclass from a great director on how to portray a meaningful story in the best way possible.Science Fiction was always an underrated genre and many people seem to hesitate giving it a chance. Arrival is the movie to convince even the toughest crowd that Sci-Fi films can be as poetic as any genre. Through slow-paced well-written plot, meaningful characters and important messages Arrival is what art should be in these days, not a cool looking movie made by a commite, but a story that reflects on reality better than any down-to-earth drama ever could, a way to express the biggest questions and answers about life.Conclusion:Arrival might not be the best sci-fi film of the decade but it's definetely among the best ones, it's a piece of art worth mentioning that will not only make you think about life, but also it will give you an emotional journey that you will never forget. Movies like this should be released more often and since this is just a hope that might never happen, give Arrival the chance it deserves to amaze you.Rating: 9/10

title: Beautiful exploration of the choices we make
review: Arrival isn't the kind of sci-fi that features starship battles or superheroes; it's the kind of sci-fi that makes you think, and brings awe and wonder to the seemingly small moments in our lives.Amy Adams is Louise Banks, a language professor hired by the military to communicate with aliens hovering in a dozen enormous vessels around the world. It's about first contact, but without the magic of "universal translators" - finding a way to communicate is hard and delicate work. Over the course of this work, Louise begins to understand life the way the aliens do, and it affects an important decision about her own path. Any more detail than that would be a spoiler; just know that the ending of this movie is emotional, bittersweet, thought-provoking, and deeply exhilarating.It's also a visually astounding movie. The first view inside the alien vessel is both minimalist and richly textured, and their written language is a gentle swirl of light and dark. The score by Icelandic composer Johann Johannsen is bookended by Max Richter's gorgeous "On the Nature of Daylight."Overall I can't recommend this movie enough - definitely in my top10 movies of all time, and #1 in science fiction.

title: watch grass grow, it's faster.
review: Why oh why would this so slow grass grows faster movie get any awards? if you're into the slow artsie fartsie crap then enjoy. if you want bang for your buck.. then pay someone to mow your lawn and watch that. I guarantee you the latter would be more entertaining.

title: The most interesting movie I've ever seen
review: This movie was more of an experience. It seems like you're being amazed for being one of those few people who are able to be there, and investigate about such a phenomenon. It feels that realistic, which makes it even more intriguing and fascinating. This movie does a more than perfect job of making the audience actively ask questions with actual interest, but it isn't so great about answering them. Why are the aliens there? The answer is given to us but it feels kind of nonsensical and stupid from a screenwriting standpoint. If only the ending wasn't so bad... This could've been a 10 so it's frustrating. It is worth it though.

title: Time is not linear
review: The first time they saw the shells was very impressive as a grandiose black object is motionless in the air. Louise the linguist and Ian the scientist goes into the shell thru a shaft in which there's no gravity and beyond a colorless glasslike things are there the two aliens aka the heptapods. Louise took off the suit and talked to them as they wrote nondirectional script of theirs. They deciphered it later and at some point a bunch of soldiers attacked the shaft thinking they're a threat to humanity. Then only Louise was taken into the shell by a vehicle separated from it and Louise got on it and was among them right behind the glass. One of them was almost dead and it said the language they speak gives them the ability to see the future just like Louise as the daughter Hannah she has and lost to cancer was actually someone from the future of hers and she's having visions of her. She will be married to Ian and had Hannah. She called the Chinese army man in charge and said the last words of his wife. And then they disappeared instantly leaving a white cloud behind them. and Ian proposed to her in the field and they lived the future that Louise already had glimpses of. It was at the first part very tense and scary the first contact and the shell itself along with the way how they ascended in the shaft without gravity but the ending is a bit anticlimactic.

title: Arrival
review:
There's a strong sense of realism to this movie. The visitors looked real, our communication problems with them seemed real, and the public's response to them felt believable.
It delivers enough scientific and intelligent material to challenge the thinking type viewer, unraveling the mystery without too much lengthy exposition. It will make you think and will grab all your attention.

title: great pacing that retained the tone that was mirrored in the Cinematography
review: Adams was exceptional in this, Jenner wasn't - that's just the lucky dip in Casting. The real acheivment in this film was sustaining the tone of the central premis and the visuals - without stagnating the experience. The choice of the colour palette, chosen by the Director is correct - but requires very strong stroylines and timing by the Actors to keep the narratibve engaging - otherwise you can drift into 3rd rate Tarkovsky. We had a step change at the end of the film that was aqbit of a leap of faith - but , ignoring that, it was still a worthwhile film for 90% of it

title: Most boring alien film you'll ever see
review:
I like space, sci fi and alien movies, but this had me bored to tears.
The cast was so cliché, the plot far fetched and the progression is slow and mundane.Good cinematography and realistic sets though.

title: Beautiful SF movie
review: I had a great experience, a visually beautiful film. I didn't watch the trailers at all, I avoided the spoilers, and the film went in a completely different direction from my expectations. And he totally surprised me and impressed me. A SF film with minimal use of CGI these days certainly deserves applause. The focus is on the story and the protagonists. The film is the total opposite of Independence Day. And then there's the plot twist, which I didn't even think of, and which is why you look at the whole movie with different eyes. Denise, every part of this accomplishment, bow to the floor. For all those who say that films are not made today as before, they obviously did not look at this top achievement. And now I wonder, isn't this the meaning of film, ie film experience? Don't watch 34 trailers that either reveal too much and ruin the viewing or misrepresent the movie and ruin the viewing. Watch visually beautiful movies, but put the emphasis on the characters and the story, not the effects. That feeling when you watch a movie and even a few days after that you think about it. I think that's the real point.

title: Super annoying, most disappointing film of the year if not decade
review: There was a time when SciFi was an exciting genre. Sadly, that era ended with Contact. Since then audiences are treated to Transformers, Interstellar, Battleship and, yes: Arrival, the "intellectual" nothingburger and masterclass in boredom and pseudo science. There's not a single character anyone cares about. Forest Whitaker, Jeremy Renner... good actors but completely wasted here. Amy Adams and that fixation with her daughter in particular is super annoying. The plot is ridiculous. Someone must have thought that putting linguistics at the centre of the story would be smart. It could be, but Arrival fails spectacularly. 12 spaceships are landing on earth and we are supposed to believe that the octopus aliens are just waiting for Amy Adams to figure out what they are trying to say. The bottom line is, this is all horrendous, flat and unexciting. 1 star for the worst film of the year. And that's without factoring in this horrible noise that passes as "original soundtrack". Good lord.

title: Don't waste your time on this sci-fi bust
review:
I kept waiting for some action in this klunker and was totally disappointed. My greatest challenge was staying awake to the finish. The most action comes when the good guys (us) almost blast away the star for making a phone call - that is exactly right, she was making a phone call (don't worry - they hold their fire)! Why did the aliens come to Earth? Answer: because they have a favor to ask of us in 3,000 years. And what did we get in return? The ability to predict the future. And why does it take 12 alien spacecraft to deliver this message? The movie gives no answer. Hell, they could have posted that on Twitter. The aliens themselves look like over-grown octopuses.
The acting is pedestrian and the writing is so-so. And when we do take on the aliens what do they use? SMALL ARMS! I mean, really, we've got a lot better stuff than that. The general should have been sacked on the spot. And they didn't exactly bust the CGI budget on this looser - the spaceship looked like a spoiled jalapeno.

title: Oh dear...my first film snob review...
review:
Yes, I will say it out loud, freely and I shall not hold back: he who does not liketh this film, does not understand it!
Do not be fooled by bad ratings or reviews for Arrival. I know this is a snob approach to rating a film but I am happy to be a snob here.
It reminds of Lost in Translation many years ago. I sat there, enjoyed it and loved the atmosphere of the film whilst I had bitterly disappointed dads with their kids sitting and waiting for Bill Murray antics and gags.
It is the same here and I get it. Anyone who expects the typical Sci-Fi formula and action will be disappointed.
Arrival is Sci-Fi, but on a whole different level. It is beautiful storytelling, about the human spirit, about what might happen when we meet other life forms, about the ability to think, to love, to look at life from a different perspective.
Absolutely magnificent.

title: Humanity
review: This film has placed a separate step on other alien films. I love the way film has written as like a live films. How would army and others take step if any object landed on earth. And the thing starting learning their languages is quit good I loved that part. Overall this film stands away for other alien invention films and one time watchable

title: Suddenly you realise... This is not a science fiction movie!!
review: Like all other Alien invasion movies, at first you think there's gonna be contact with Aliens... They'll suck up the Earth's resources and all the usual stuff but no.. The climax of the movie is so anti-climatic.. It makes you think.. What will you do if you get a chance to relive your life knowing the exact start and end of the current one.. I processed that in my mind.. And my lips softly uttered "NO".. If was a beautiful realisation that made me feel I'm already happy with my life.. Oh god.. What a movie!!!

title: This movie is a disappointment to me
review: The beginning of the movie is just outstanding, it hooks you in spite of the slow pace. It has some very interesting ideas and concepts but it fails mostly because of one thing in my opinion and that's time travel. Any movie that uses time travel as an essential plot point has to be very particular with the rules to make me engage with that aspect. I did not engage with this movie's version at all. In fact, all the intrigue and drama it had built up just fell flat as soon as the concept of going back and forth in time was introduced and I lost all engagement with the movie.May be different for you as it seems is for the rest of the reviewers that are giving it a 10/10 but it's just not for me. A shame since I was really looking forward to how things were going to go. In any case, it is probably worth watching but it is a very slow and weird movie.I hope more movies like this are made favorably without an element of time-travel (Interstellar is another one that lost me because of that).

title: Miss
review: This movie was close to being good but ended up falling short. First off, the movie had exceptional cinematography, acting and an interesting premise. That was the good. Unfortunately, there was a lot of bad in this movie as well. The whole premise that language can suddenly make you see the future, was both underutilized and makes no sense. I don't care what language you speak, there is no way possible you can use a language to help you see in the future, because it literally hasn't happened yet. I understand the language hypothesis, but I still don't buy it. The future thing was also underutilized. Amy Adams could only see up to her child dying. Could she see beyond her death, up to her death? What about 3000 years later, could she see what was going to happen?My other problem, aside from the plothole, was the fact that the movie didn't know what it wanted to be. Is this movie an Alien take over movie which is about human civilization or is it a deep movie about family and living life? In the end, I had no idea because the movie was so all over the place. At one point civilization has come together and she is explaining the Alien language and at the other Renner is whispering 'let's make a baby' into her ear and their playing with their kid. What is the message in this movie? If it is that Aliens can bring us together, why include the child part and if it is to live our life the same even if we know the future why include the alien part?I didn't find the movie boring as some others have suggested and I thought it kept things interesting even if it was simple at times. Also, I saw the Jeremy Renner being her husband coming from a mile away (around when it was revealed she hadn't already had the child).For the major plothole and the mixed theme I give this movie a 6/10

title: First contact done right ! Stop what you you are doing and watch it now (again) !
review: A well crafted movie with a dense thrilling atmosphere and an emotional story delivered by an brilliant performance by Amy Adams.The story (without spoilers) is a mix of Close Encounters of the Third Kind and Contact, but also adds something new and modern to the sci-fi genre.The music helps to create the dramatic and dense atmosphere and also supports the emotional moments. (won Academy Award for Best Sound Editing)All in all one of the best (when not the best) Sci-Fi movie of the last decade and a must watch for all movie fans. The director Denis Villeneuve knows what he is doing and set a very high bar for movie making in general and is probably in the top 3 best directors of the 21th century list (eg. Prisoners, Sicario and the only other competitor for Arrival what a suprise Blade Runner 2049).

title: Masterpiece
review: This is a masterpiece.The photo, the images, the colours, the script, the light, the music. Everything thing is just balanced as it should be.The aliens are not green or like in Alien I, II etc. They are so beautiful and "unconventional".And the dilemma is so sad and interesting at the same time.It's a must see movie. Definitely.

title: Good Entertainer
review: So aliens have landed...Government aware...check....Military involved and paranoid...check....curious scientist with unique abilities...check.So yes it is formulaic.However the presentation of the significant alien uniqueness (compared to other movie aliens) is really well done as is the atmosphere created and the tensions between all the involved protagonists.We have been here and done this before but it is still really enjoyable :)

title: Not all intergalactic species came to hunt us
review: The way in which time is portrayed in the movie is quite phenomenal & sometimes can be little bit problematic to understand.The heptapods helping in global unification & their gift to Dr Louise gives you a great cinematic experience. Don't expect too much actions or actions at all from the movie jst enjoy the story & it's narration.

title: TRUE and PHILOSOPHICAL Science-Fiction
review: This is exactly what I want to see when paying for a cinema ticket!Denis Villeneuve is a true visual artist, with high creativity and deep understanding of the power good pictures/shots can have. He takes his time to take the viewer into the moment and let him feel the imagined atmosphere as good as possible. (I'm really looking forward to his interpretation of Dune!)I must point out the incredible and majestic one-take shot of the protagonists arriving to the place the ,Arrival' happend, in which Villeneuve presents us in an over 2min long, no talking one-shot, one of the (in my eyes) best ,First visual Contact' scenes ever made. Captivating sound and atmosphere! Brilliantly executed!This rather calm Sci-Fi movie is low paced with a lot subtile elements. The storyline itself is actually not complex on the surface, but has a highly complex and philosophical idea in its core! This makes it a multiple watch movie that demands way more from the audience than the average flick.It has good but no groundbreaking performances by the actors, but built in an all around great atmospheric environment, they are believable as well as their behavior.All together a MUST for experienced and demanding Sci-Fi watchers and a fantastic opportunity for everybody else to see a movie from the true genre of Science-Fiction!

title: Great plot about Linguistics and Time Travel
review: I´ve always liked the time travel theme in movies. This is a very good one in my opinion. It resembles a little bit 1980´s "Somewhere in Time" stared by Christopher Reeve. Above all, it makes me wonder about the possibilities of seeing the future or the past again just changing the way we define and use our language. It definitely influenced me to study about the fascinatiing world of linguistics. By the way, it has a good message about solidarity and union among us beyond nationalities, especially in these days which are marked by regressive ideas across the world. Not even the ongoing pandemic seems to make us think in a different perspective, I mean, as Humankind.

title: Be patient to watch it until end, because the "kick" is at the ending.
review: As a whole, this is a really good movie, brilliant way of storytelling and very nice cinematographyThe first 3/4 of the movie might bore you, but you just have to be patient and finish it until the end. The ending is remarkable as it re-construct the whole story in a totally different perspective. I am so amazed what the ending did to my surprise. It's totally unpredictable.Anyway I don't really feel fit about the concept of the alien in this movie, I think it's quite absurd. An alien supposed to be an intelligent creature with sophisticated technology, but the movie just provides an octopus-like alien with magical power.Had it not due to the absurdity of the alien, I would have given a perfect score, it's just 9/10 from me. Well done.

title: Awe inspiring
review: I just watched it a second time after 2 years I think and all the pieces clicked together. I could see the trail that led to the end so perfectly that when the ending came I bawled my eyes out next to my family who were watching with me.One of the most beautiful movies I have had the honor to see in my life. Masterpiece. I cannot wait for Villeneuve's Dune.

title: One of the best sci-fi's you'll see
review: Never have a seen such a methodical, realistic, contemplative approach to science fiction in recent cinema history. If you're expecting blockbuster action, or an epic space saga, then this might not be for you. But if you're looking for something mature, philosophical, and suspenseful, you'll love it. Villeneuve has a talent for creating wonderful stretches of tension with the well-written dialogue. The attention to realism, from the initial social and military response to their arrival, to the motives and histories of the characters, are all very well done. The pacing is wonderful, as is the exploration of time. The music is nicely chosen as well, and really adds to the meaning of the movie. I would definitely put Villeneuve among my favourite directors (along with Nolan and Cameron). If you enjoy mature and philosophical movies and science fiction, you'll enjoy this.

title: Overrated
review: It didn't bore me and I liked the idea of the movie. But it's written based on an idea, there is no meaningful script. There are some elements to gain the attention and you give your attention but there is no logic behind it.

title: Lower Your Expectations
review: When I saw this movie was nominated for Best Adapted Screenplay I expected to watch something good. I'm not saying it's a bad movie but there is no script. There is an idea and that's all. That's why they added some different elements in it but still it doesn't have an actual script.

title: FOR THOSE WHO DIDN'T LIKE IT:
review: If you didn't like this movie, it might be because you overlooked an important, easy-to-miss detail. The complex story is very well hidden inside what could be an otherwise boring movie. You have to pay close attention to every word, and consider the possibility that anything could mean something entirely different. Keep studying and analyzing every detail throughout the movie, then the real story will come together in the end. If a distraction caused you to miss just one event or one line of dialogue, you might never understand what's really happening. And the scrambled timeline in this movie adds to the challenge. I did not fully understand the story until I had watched it a couple times. This is one of the greatest movies ever made, but half the audience disliked it because they expect to be entertained the way other movies do. This movie doesn't do that. It makes you work for it.

title: I saw myself in the future giving this a ten
review: And now I have to. Anything else would be a spoiler.

title: Mind-grappling, but forced
review: You sense what has become Denis's trademark touch from top to bottom: the moody score and instrospective atmosphere. The movie builds up with interesting and original ideas. However, by the ending, he's just trying too hard to be meaningful... I mean, an English professor who becomes a fortune teller because she can read circles? Come on... I won't even get into the child cancer situation.

title: Okay movie, horrible adaption
review:
I quite liked it when it came out, general vibe of scientists pulled out by government for top secret project always gives me chills. And it's quite beautiful artistically.
Story didn't have much sense, but I was mostly okay with it.Oh boy, that changed when I read original story this film is based on. Original story is actually very interesting science fiction, exploring one intriguing physics principle, which got me thinking for days. I wouldn't consider this film a waster of my time just because I heard about this story because of it.
But film itself absolutely and miserably fails to show beauty of original premise. It absurdly mutilate original plot, and without basic idea explained or even mentioned it looks just stupid and doesn't have any sense.It looks like movie makers couldn't understand science principle behind original, but they were told to copy all the aftermath, so that's what they did without any thinking and logic. Result is just embarrassing.

review:

title: Modern Science Fiction masterpiece
review: Arrival was directed by Dennis Villeneuve and stars Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner and Forrest Whittaker. When 12 alien spaceships land on Earth, linguist Louis Banks and physicist Ian Donnelly are recruited by the U.S. Government to find out the intentions of the aliens. They attempt to decode the complex alien language amid escalating international and domestic tensions. I think that it should be included in the pantheon of great science fiction films. While packed with complex ideas and themes, Arrival is also a deeply emotional and contemplative movie. Amy Adams is great in the lead role. She excellently depicts the wonder and shock that her character experiences. The musical score is also brilliant in heightening the complex emotions experienced by the characters. Most of the movie is deliberately paced with long-takes and wide shots showcasing the beauty and the immensity of the aliens. The film expertly connects communication, language, time and human existence in a thoroughly absorbing experience. One of the best movies of the decade.

title: Arrival. (2016)
review: Clever science fiction film with an Oscar-worthy Amy Adams who skillfully tells a story that makes the viewer think and asks the question: What would you do yourself in the situation?

title: a movie that will make you feel nervous and intense BUT, I expected more.
review: Arrival is a movie that will make you feel nervous and intense BUT, I expected more.Arrival is a movie that I really enjoyed, the first act of the movie made me excited, want to see more and want to know what will happen at the end, to be more specific, I wanted an answer to the question "why are they here?", and the first act builds that so well.Amy Adams' (plays: Dr. Louise Banks) performance was absolutely incredible and so powerful, loved her character and her acting was amazing, her face expressions, body language, and her eyes are everything, she was acting with everything. Forest Whitaker (Plays: Colonel Weber) was also amazing, very cool performance that surprised me. Jeremy Renner's character (Ian Donnelly) was so useless, even the character said that in one of the scenes, he said that he is nothing without Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) and she is the one who is doing everything.The directing was so amazing wasn't surprised that Denis Villeneuve was nominated for an Oscar.The cinematography and colors were so amazing, especially that shot when we first see the aliens aircraft, the incredible long take encompassing the entire area with the fog surrounding it, loved it so much. One thing that grabbed my attention is the whole "color tone", the off white-ish color that is dark, gives u that feeling of fear, feeling of confusion of why these aliens are here, it was just amazing and really loved it so much.The music was so cool, it builds a lot of emotions inside of you.the production design was so beautiful and simple, deserved an Oscar nomination.The sound editing and sound mixing were two things that were really powerful and although I didn't watch that movie on the big screen with all the sound effects that are in the theatre, but it was still a thing that was so amazing and grabbed my attention.Arrival is a movie that is not the best but also not the worst, the 3rd act or to be specific; the ending makes you want to watch the movie again and makes you think about the movie from its beginning. A great story with a great directing, cinematography and production design but felt like it could've been way better but i for sure recommend it.My rating is: 8/10

title: One of, if not my favourite Sci-fi film
review: So glad it took the overdone alien first contact action flick and added a realistic setting. Highly grounded in sci-fi is what makes this one of my favourite films.Rewatched it for the first, after 3 years. Remember vividly a lot of stuffs, one the few movies I used to constantly think about 3 years ago. Script is a masterpiece, way to tell that story in that way, beautiful. The concept of time travel seen in a new light.The soundtrack is addicting, was listening to it out loud and my mother told me to stop it because it felt like 'someone was dying', I replied HannaH.The cinematography of that first scene of spaceship was gorgeous. Many social commentary about conspiracy theory, majority of them were correct as we can see from pandemic. I actually gained a lot of respect for linguistics, always thought of it as a useless study area but boy was I wrong.Rewatching it, caught many foreshadowing. The movie literally says everything at the beginning.Loved the themes, her taking the decision of have that child. Its not about the goodbyes but the memories we make before the goodbyes. She would rather find & lost than never get it. The parallelism with one the heptapods(alien) dying yet the other one not caring because their time isn't linear, they could go back in memory.Script was smart to have that Chinese official scene, many will say it was plot convenience but I have head canon of her later telling the Chinese official to tell her everything later on, hence he had a line 'I don't know how your brain/memory works'The movie did answer why aliens came but it wasn't concerned with that, it was more about humanity and their perspective & memories. This is CINEMA.Type of movie I will end and sleep on thinking about it. The calm and eerie feeling filled me after the credits.

title: Unwatchable because it's TOO DARK
review: I've been reading IMDB review for ages and made the effort to register solely to write this review, because there comes a point when you can't keep quiet and must say enough is enough.If there were an option to chose NO STARS, I would have. This is the first movie in my 63 years that I had simply could not watch after a few minutes trying. I thought there was something wrong with the film but after checking a few scenes at random, I have found out that alas, it was made unwatchable BY DESIGN >:-(Why, oh why did Denis Villeneuve think it was OK to underexpose his movie so severely you're constantly trying to make out what the scenes shows BECAUSE THEY ARE SO GODDAMN DARK?! After 2 minutes of this torture I could not stand it anymore. Thank God for Netflix, at least I didn't have to pay extra for watching this torture for the eyes.And I'm not saying that because I don't appreciate visual arts - I've been a photographer since early teens and use a $3,000 color calibrated graphics monitor on my PC with 10 bit IPS LCD and it's the first movie I ever I had to stop watching after just a few minutes - it's that painful to watch.For now I'll read the novel the movie was based on (Story of Your Life, by Ted Chiang), and hope a gamma corrected version of the movie comes out (like I hope someone will one day stabilize the Bourne movie series to remove camera shake to a bearable level). One can hope, right?This fad of making movies painful to watch is not new and in fact seems to be getting worse and is certainly going to be remembered as a 'dark' period in the history of movie making, because great movies are those that make themselves invisible to the point the viewer really believes he is in the story, and forcing the viewer to look for luminosity and contrast controls totally breaks this fundamental principle.It's too bad Denis Villeneuve made this decision, as his sequel to Bladerunner is the best sequel to any movie I've ever seen, a true masterpiece on its own.

title: Interestingly different
review: The best thing in this movie is the linguistic angle. The difficulty of communicating with a completely different lifeform is handled in quite a creative and intelligent manner. Also the way aliens and the ship are presented is also among the most believeable. No english speaking humans with a bump in forehead here. The time part of the storyline is unscientific and makes this less a scifi classic and more a fairytale. Military idiots did not need to be in this story. Does Hollywood have an oblication to put them in every film? The colonel (Forest Whitaker) is a refreshingly smart soldier though.Amy Adams excels in the leading role as the liguistics professor facing an almost impossible challenge. She's both strong and delicate in a way that captivates you all the way through.Overall my feelings of Arrival are mixed. What's good is really good, but the weaknesses are all the more frustrating.

title: Amazing
review: Denis Villeneuve won me over with this film. It is a masterpiece of science fiction that has a real emotional core. It is ostensibly about aliens and treats this subject matter carefully and without sensationalism. It explores topics like linguistics and time that are not often treated in these films. However, there is also the human element which ties into the twisted timelines and it really underpins the entire experience. The only thing I would give it fault for is the odd diversion with the soldiers' conspiracy theories - otherwise I would have rated this ten out of ten!

title: A smart and captivating Sci-Fi thriller
review: Arrival is definitely not your average action-packed blockbuster Sci-Fi movie. Through great character development, smart writing and a careful use of CGI, it manages to create a very unique atmosphere which maintains a tight tension throughout. Arrival also displays a really creative design and is overall visually pleasing. A great watch.

title: Arrival? More like Departure from Everything Good about Villeneuve
review: If you like having exposition crammed down your throat by two comically inept academics, you will love Arrival.It's one of those films that tells you all about science and life, but only does this by relying on the complete ineptitude and gullibility of its audience. If you have never met a linguist, you will love the way this film depicts them. They're simple, really. They look at words, and then they try to figure out what they mean. However, in pressure-filled situations, where it would be imperative for them to really understand a new language, they implement the amazing strategy of standing around and telling each other how linguistics works. This is a fantastic technique in case anyone happened to be spying on them who didn't have any common sense.Plus - Arrival also features one of those classic anthropocentric plots that audiences ate up in Interstellar. If you like cosmically significant sci-fi stories that somehow always manage to mostly be about one character's relationship with their child, this film will scratch that itch too!Arrival comes at the departure of the last breath of dignity that north american film audiences ever managed to breathe. It truly is a masterpiece of vapid blast-you-in-the-face blockbuster cliches. The diversity of scenes and the artistic nuances will dazzle and amaze you. From Amy Adams staring into the middle distance with a thin depth of field, to Amy Adams staring into the middle distance with swelling background music, this film really features every angle of Amy Adams almost crying that audiences could ever want.And if that wasn't enough, the rest of film is dripping with sentimentality too. It you're one of the great many lemmings in this world, Arrival invites you wholeheartedly to listen for it's subtle hints to *cry! cry you fool! the world is filled with obvious tragedy and sadness!* and to revel as the tears well up in your pristine lemming face. It gives you no reason to feel these feelings, just the general sense that they are appropriate, and a couple of flashbacks involving a child to make it really hit home.You know, the only truly sad thing is that this film features amazing concepts, amazing actors, amazing sets, and amazing effects. I mean that in all seriousness. Yet, the whole thing is ruined by a barren script, monotone directing, and cinematography at the level of your average indie youtube film. Whoever nominated Villeneuve for that Oscar must have either been an ancient astronaut theorist, or perpetually high.And I take no pleasure in saying this because most of Villeneuve's other work is so promising. Enemy was genuinely amazing and innovative, and Incendies was top-tier filmmaking. But the greatest among us fall the hardest. And I fear that Arrival may ironically signal the departure of everything I love about Villeneuve's work. Hopefully Dune sees a return to his roots.

title: ' I forgot how much I loved you holding me''
review:
' I forgot how much I loved you holding me''Whow what a blast...
Arrival released a couple of years ago, I remember I watched it first on Plane from Istanbul to Frankfurt and was to tired to follow.
Now we have the year 2020, the corona lockdown gave us more time than we need to finish our watchlist and so it was time for Arrival.
it is not easy to tell how brilliant this movie is without Spoiler anything.
The music is deeply sad and lovable combined with the pictures and the arty storytelling of Dennis Villeneuve it will suck you right in and you have no chance of release before the end credits roll over your TV screen.
I know the most of us expect a ScFi flick with Aliens and Soldiers and saving the world stuff like so many times before, but here is much more under the surface.
It is a melodramatic palindrome that will you make think days after you have watched it, and delivers a powerful message about the importance of Communication.
Time is non-linear as this picture portrays.
In it's all simplicity it gives you an infinite possibility of past, present and future.
This is one of the rare movies that we are all so fortunate to experience, sometimes the best pictures are the ones that require us thinking more than sheer entertainment.Just beautiful, magnificent and tragic...
''come back to me''

title: Overrated
review: The movie is incredibly slow, especially the first hour. I also thought it was annoying how they kept trying to tease the aliens. The first few times they didn't show the alien ship, and the very first glimpse of the aliens lasted a split second. They did show them later, but I found this to be an annoying way to create suspense.In the first half it is really just some linguist's ultimate dream: just deciphering an alien language.Some of the deciphering bit is interesting, but not that much. There's only two noteworthy characters and our protagonist is moody throughout the film. And the scenery is always dark. All of this makes for a long winding movie.That being said, the visuals are good. The ending with the plot twist was unexpected and interesting.

The timelines in the film may sometimes make it boring to make the film beautiful, but also complicated because it is slow but acting and the information we learned will be the reason for us to continue the movie.Denis Villeneuve loves space-related movies after this movie, he shot the Blade Runner 2049 and it was really good even that movie had a completely different style and now I am waiting with agreement for the Dune movie.

title: Wow wow wow wow wow
review: ...that's one Wow for each time I saw this amazing, thought provoking, fenomenally executed movie.Saw it back in 2016 and still, 4 years later, Arrival leaves me speechless.The original short story by Ted Chiang is probably one of the finest works of science fiction I ever read (I read it after I saw the movie for the first time), nothing short of Isaac Asimov, Ray Bradbury, Stanislaw Lec, Arthur C Clarke and other famous writers of the genre. The movie follows the book closely enough, with just enough additional plot developed masterly by Eric Heisserer into a screenplay that gave Dennis Villeneuve more than enough material to showcase his exceptional talent, and Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker to show us one more time how good the actors they truly are (especially Ms Adams - what a wonderful, awe-inspiring performance!). The cinematography is one of the highlights of the movie, word "impeccable" comes to mind. Editing, light and sound effects - perfect. In other words, all elements of this movie are in a perfect sync.In closing: I respect everyone's opinion and if one hated this movie, I understand it. HOWEVER, I wouldn't go see Superman vs Batman and post 1 star review on IMDB afterwards, but that's me: my life is too short to be wasted on bad cinema. But if I do not understand a movie, as many of those who hated Arrival obviously did not, I would try to at least stay away from the keyboard. But all hope is not lost: we cannot have presidents tweet stupidities and proper movie haters post bad reviews forever...

review: This was one of, if not the, best movies I've ever seen. For a film with little action its incredibly enthralling. The story could not have been more beautiful. To me it's about love, life, and understanding. Loving to its fullest without fear of the heartaches or pain that may come from it. Living in the moment and appreciating every second of it. And understanding that all life, regardless of how near or far from our planet, regardless of species or language or skin color or creed or religion, are all connected. title: Just amazing...
review: Screenwriter Eric Heisserer originally read this science fiction story. It had a profound effect on him, and he pushed for it to be made into a movie.I can see why. This is a great story. We have some many pre concieved ideas about it, its sort of corny, there are really limited things that can happen...are we dealing with rubber aliens, etc.Despite this, the movie is a complex story, about human emotion, love, family, and humanity.Amy adams, Jeremy Renner are both excellent in this, expecially Adams, the film largely centres on her. There are limited sets locales, but the drama and intensity carries throught.If you like thought provoking, challenging science fiction, this is for you. If you want something else, probably go and see independance day.

title: Fermat's principle
review: "Arrival" is different from the general science fiction movies. It flows on the level of objects and the objective world, and innovatively expands the field to the level of human consciousness, cognition and spirit.The setting of the story is based on a hypothesis of linguistics-Sapir-Woolf hypothesis. This hypothesis connects language with thinking, and believes that the language used by a person affects his cognition and way of thinking subtly. The "English thinking" of the English learning institution in real life may find a trace here. English is the main sentence with the main sentence, and the branch is the branching branch of the branch. Nesting, the difference in the essential characteristics of this language, may affect the way of thinking of different peoples.Louise, the heroine of "Arrival", is a top linguist, changing the way she perceives the world while learning the language "seven languages" of the alien "seven limbs". "Seven languages" is different from any language on earth. Our language is a linear structure, which determines that we must listen to or read a whole sentence in order to know the meaning of this sentence. Seven-language is a non-linear ring structure language, that is, the language of "God's perspective", from The two-dimensional level extends to the three-dimensional or even four-dimensional level. There is no strict causal logic and order, and it is a "lake" composed of sentences and words.Seven-language users are not constrained by linear time, and can stand on a high place overlooking the time, just like a writer who understands the cause, process, climax, and ending of the entire film; the writer is well aware of his novel structure and characters. The female lead gained spoilers for her life because she learned the seven languages, and foresees her life early.This kind of foresight is certainly good: she saw her husband 's tender chestnut eyes in advance, and heard the intimate love words when drinking tango; she saw in advance the soft braided braids, a pair of small dimples filled with sweet, will With a pair of small hands squeezing the plasticine, and using a wonderful pen to graffiti the little girl with the child's naive and casual style painting, she feels the beauty of love in advance, the comfort of a mother, the joy of growing up with children.This kind of foresight also carries tragic cruelty: her daughter has turned into a bare bone that is pale and almost transparent under the white cloth of the bed because of an incurable genetic disease; her husband who was informed of her daughter 's ending in advance is angry and helpless Choose to leave Louise early to escape the fate of her daughter's death.Here is a serious philosophical question for the viewer: if you foresee every step of your life, will you choose to change? The smallness of the individual and the force majeure of destiny intermingle, creating an irreversible deep tragedy, just as the prophecy of King Oedipus 's father and his mother marrying him. Every struggling and hard work in his life is just to let himself slide towards each step The preset ending; the curse of the sleeping beauty who was pierced by the spindle and fell asleep, and the foolproof protection still has a gap for fate to enter. Since the efforts cannot be changed, many people choose to escape like their husbands, and it is not shameful to escape, but it is absolutely respectable to be brave and frank.Louise's line at the end of the movie is very touching: "Despite knowing the journey, and where it leads, I embrace it, and I welcome every moment." Even though I already know this journey and its destination, I still greet it and greet it Every minute per second.The film's original novel "The Story of Your Life" is alternately narrated in the first and second person, as if Louise is sitting by her daughter's bed, with a peaceful smile, telling her the story of her life. The deep tension and timeless humor contained in the lines of the words make readers can't help but respect the woman who knows her destiny but does not escape and elegantly goes to the appointment.The end of each life can't escape from the incinerator into ashes, and wait for decay in the soil. From the beginning, we know the certain ending of death, but will the fertilized egg use this as a reason to escape the initial split? Regardless of whether the ending is separation or death, we treat the characters that appear in life with the most fierce sincerity. We take every step calmly, embrace every minute and second, and walk gently to death.

title: One of My Favorite of All Time
review: Tonight I needed a cathartic experience, and instead of escapism, I opted for doubling down on a good cry. I love this movie with all my heart. It is just so beautiful, sad, yet hopeful, and ultimately uplifting. By this point, Denis Villeneuve could film paint drying and I will be there for it. He can do no wrong in my book, as he just made a magnificent symphony of visuals and sounds, aided by a breathtaking performance by Amy Adams that was criminally under appreciated. And just as powerful was the use of music in this film especially the brilliant Max Richter's piece "On the Nature of Daylight" which is employed from the first scene and throughout the film fitting like hand a glove. There is no question in my mind that Arrival is my favorite film of 2016, and one of my favorite films of all time.

title: Convoluted film
review: I love science fiction, but I found this movie hard to follow and overly long. How can one two-person team figure out the alien language in that short of time? Granted, in the beginning they were part of 12 different teams working and sharing, but all of their team's ideas came to fruition when no other team's did?The time-travel thing was put there only to expedite the ending of the movie. It made for an interesting ending, but come on now - only Louis is able to do it, plus she's able to be in the present and the future at the same time? That's a stretch I don't believe in.Louis disobeys orders over and over again. yet this military-run project lets her continue to do so. In the middle there was a scene where the "shift" was over, yet she went into the staging area without permission and made the movie's major breakthrough while our own troops were firing on each other. Another unbelievable premise.The aliens were interesting. It was like that Star Trek episode where Picard and an alien culture almost come to war until he figures out that they speak in metaphors.
